results.abstract: Hilda Cole Espy article recalls weekends spent at West Point as 'drag,' or guest of cadet; describes noteworthy sites and activities open to visitors to acad; illus (L)
results.snippet: I USED to weekend at West Point as the "drag" of a cadet. I meandered on Flirtation Walk, sang  "Brave Old Army Team" at football games, watched parades and danced at "hops" in Cuilum Hall. Hops were always formal then--receiving line, long ...

results.abstract: Apollo 14 astronaut Stuart A Roosa plants sycamore tree near Phila's Independence Hall from seeds taken to moon and back by Apollo 14 spacecraft; says planting is 1st of Bicentenntal events focusing on forest resources (S)

headline.main: Notes on People; Women's Unit Hail's Betty Ford

results.snippet: Betty Ford took credit yesterday for her husband's appointment of a woman to the Cabinet and added, "I'm working on getting a woman on the Supreme Court as soon as possible."
results.lead_paragraph: Betty Ford took credit yesterday for her husband's appointment of a woman to the Cabinet and added, "I'm working on getting a woman on the Supreme Court as soon as possible."

results.abstract: Christina Onassis expected to fly to US for business talks; meets with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis in London; repts that Christina's marriage to Peter Goulandris will not take place soon, if at all, noted (S)

headline.main: Notes on People; Harriman Defines and Defends Detente

results.snippet: "I'm very much opposed to using French words," said W. Averell Harriman in Moscow, where he told American journalists that many of their countrymen were either "cynical" about or "oversold" on detente because they do not understand it.
results.lead_paragraph: "I'm very much opposed to using French words," said W. Averell Harriman in Moscow, where he told American journalists that many of their countrymen were either "cynical" about or "oversold" on detente because they do not understand it.

results.snippet: THE WHOLESALE PRICE INDEX rose to 172.1 in April [1967-100], an increase of 1.5 per cent over the March level. Agricultural price increases presage a rise in retail food prices, but advances in industrial prices were small ...

results.abstract: USSR permits foreign newsmen to visit main flight control center, Kaliningrad, for 1st time in preparation for joint Apollo Soyuz Project; center described; tech dir Albert V Milstein says center was built in '70 and was 1st used on manned flight to direct flight of Soyuz 12; center is believed to handle unmanned Cosmos missions; Milstein says press corps will not be allowed in center during actual mission; Amer technicians already installed at center in preparation for flight; map (M)

headline.main: U.S. Newsmen Visit Soviet Space Center

results.snippet: KALININGRAD, U.S.S.R., May 12-The Soviet Union peeled away one more layer of secrecy from its space program today and for the first time permitted foreign newsmen to inspect its main flight control center.

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: KALININGRAD, U.S.S.R., May 12-The Soviet Union peeled away one more layer of secrecy from its space program today and for the first time permitted foreign newsmen to inspect its main flight control center.

results.abstract: Nancy Lyon article on stained-glass; discusses basic skills of craft and suggests books describing techniques; illus (L)

headline.main: Colorful Creations In Stained Glass; Creations in Stained Glass

results.snippet: My earliest appreciation of stained glass was as a glorious escape from boredom during church services. I would sit through dull sermons watching the colors in the stained glass windows dim and brighten as clouds passed the sun, studying the lead...

results.abstract: Former Apollo astronaut Charles Conrad Jr reptdly will be named to head FAA; por (M)
results.snippet: The White House decided this week to name a former astronaut, Charles Conrad Jr., to head the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Government sources, but is reconsidering because of issues raised in a Senate vote against reinstating the...
results.lead_paragraph: The White House decided this week to name a former astronaut, Charles Conrad Jr., to head the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Government sources, but is reconsidering because of issues raised in a Senate vote against reinstating the last F.A.A. chief as a retired colonel.

results.abstract: USSR launches Soyuz 18 spacecraft, with cosmonauts Lt Col Pyotr Klimuk and Vitaly I Sevastyanov aboard, for expected linkup with orbiting Salyut space station; chief of Soviet astronaut training Lt Gen Vladimir A Shatalov says mission is aimed at testing individual elements and systems of Soyuz spacecraft and to search for new possibilities in use of individual and group of spacecraft to accomplish scientific experiments in near-earth orbit; cosmonauts illus (M)

headline.main: Soviet Orbits Crew For Station Linkup; Soviet Orbits Soyuz Crew for Linkup With Station

results.snippet: MOSCOW, May 24--The Soviet Union launched today a manned Soyuz spacecraft for an expected linkup with Salyut 4, a space research station in orbit since last December.

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, May 24--The Soviet Union launched today a manned Soyuz spacecraft for an expected linkup with Salyut 4, a space research station in orbit since last December.

results.abstract: W Sullivan on theory that numerous light flashes observed by Skylab astronauts as they flew through South Atlantic Anomaly--slight asymmetry in earth's magnetic field--is attributable to cosmic rays; notes Skylab penetrated lowest layer of Van Allen radiation belt over Brazil, where force lines of field are displaced downward and in which trapped particles seem to have atomic nuclei heavier than hydrogen; observations by Skylab astronauts recalled (M)

headline.main: Skylab Tests Point to Cosmic Ray Layer

results.snippet: Numerous light flashes observed by astronauts aboard a Skylab as they flew through the South Atlantic Anomaly last year have been interpreted as evidence for a previously unsuspected form of radiation there.
results.lead_paragraph: Numerous light flashes observed by astronauts aboard a Skylab as they flew through the South Atlantic Anomaly last year have been interpreted as evidence for a previously unsuspected form of radiation there.
